summary: Email chain between prosecutors and defense attorneys regarding document requests in the criminal case against Jeffrey Epstein following his death. The emails discuss routing requests to the civil division, the anticipated entry of a nolle prosequi order, and the potential return/destruction of prior discovery.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased defendant in the criminal case United States v. Jeffrey Epstein, 19-CRIM-00490.

persons.name: Michael C. Miller
persons.context: Partner at Steptoe & Johnson LLP who sent document requests to prosecutors on behalf of Epstein's legal team.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Copied on the email from Michael Miller regarding document requests in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Martin G. Weinberg
persons.context: Copied on the email from Michael Miller regarding document requests in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Jason Meade
persons.context: Addressed in the email chain regarding handling of document requests from Epstein's lawyers.

connections.description: Miller is sending document requests on behalf of Epstein's legal team following Epstein's death.
Weingarten is copied on legal correspondence regarding document requests in Epstein's case.
Weinberg is copied on legal correspondence regarding document requests in Epstein's case.
Miller is communicating with prosecutor Meade regarding document requests and service of legal correspondence.

events.title: Document Requests Following Epstein's Death
events.description: Epstein's lawyers send document requests to prosecutors regarding the criminal case, which prosecutors plan to route to the civil division.

events.title: Anticipated Nolle Prosequi Order
events.description: Prosecutors anticipate the entry of a nolle prosequi order (declination to prosecute) following Epstein's death.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died while in custody at MCC, leading to discussions about closing the criminal case.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died in August 2019 while his criminal case (19-CRIM-00490) was pending in the Southern District of New York.
Following Epstein's death, prosecutors anticipated entering a nolle prosequi order and planned to request return/destruction of prior discovery.
Epstein's lawyers (including Michael C. Miller, Reid Weingarten, and Martin G. Weinberg) were making document requests to the DOJ, FBI, and MCC.
Prosecutors indicated no further productions would occur in the criminal case due to Epstein's death and the pending nolle prosequi.
The email chain shows coordination between criminal and civil divisions of the DOJ regarding handling of post-death legal requests.
